PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Don't feel obliged to answer all, there is not sufficient space to answer all questions. If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events; it may help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVE QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not able to do so, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Jacob G. Andres
2. Your address: Box 34, Laird, Sask.
3. Date: July 13, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Village of Kamenka, Eastern Russia
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Gerhard Andres, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year): April 1894
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Dec. 1891 - Apr. 1894 in Manitoba.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," I was ill by reason, etc.) I was 11 years old.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? Because Father had 6 sons and he wanted to place them on farms.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through my uncle, a government agent, Mr. Klaus Peters, who came to Russia to invite immigrants to Canada. Also through The Northwest Paper "Der Nordwesten" published in Winnipeg.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It as a place to settle? Yes, they were several families, particularly we helped many people, but we didn't go there ourselves.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to report? We had by far, about 65 miles, then it proved a vast place. In the spring, for many decades, we found it very difficult to get our crops ready. We had no fences, so we had to build them all ourselves. The first year was very hard, but we managed to survive.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

25. Did you build your own house very often? How much did it cost?

26. Our first church, built by hope, which we started about 10 miles from the North Beach, was completed and dedicated in June 1976.
20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, what was their name?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? Give all the facts about it.

I took my wife to Prince Albert by train, about 15 miles, then we traveled into town. In the spring, we saw many Indians preparing their move and decided to join them. We kept our feet warm and used it properly. We moved our goods, filled them with wood and hay, and started. The trip was hard, but we arrived at our destination.

We had a great deal of pleasure breaking the land, and the first house we built was at Prince Albert. We were naturally glad to have it almost done, since at times, the work was almost too much. Didn't you travel about much in the early years? For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.? How often? By what means of travel?

We traveled by horse for leisure, attended church and visited friends. It took about two weeks every month.

Our first school, built of logs, which we started about 10 miles from the North Beach, was completed and dedicated in June 1917.

30. When did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

We came to stay.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have? For moving?

Yes, two people moved.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did number grow?

More than formerly. Just now retired.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Was elected to Board school for 3 years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, Villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in name since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts as above in (1), (2), (3).

Wallace had a name. It was applied to the town because it was a place for many Indians to settle around and named it because of the famous mission founded there. It was named after the first district school, which again is the meaning of the Indian name. The area was called "Wallace."

Tiefengrund' Bishop David James named it. It was named after the story book, and the present district named it. They have followed up and continued it. But the mail went along this way. They have followed up and then to Battleford.

County School, was named because of some official in the Railway Co. hearing that name.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1927? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, no explanation provided.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did they move away permanently or temporarily?

Many moved away permanently.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and origin; (2) suggestions; (3) any charges in name since the first name was given; (4) any reason for change.

Walker's Hill was named after the old man who lived there. It was originally called "Walker's Hill" because it was owned by Mr. Walker.
